Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Summer Fellowships in Biogeochemistry and Climate Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award continues an REU (Research Experiences for Undergraduates) Site program in Biogeochemistry and Climate at the University of California, Irvine's Department of Earth System Science. The principal goal of the program is to inspire and encourage qualified undergraduate students to seek graduate training in the Earth Sciences and to contribute to the generation of new knowledge and solutions for societal problems related to climate change. Over a period of nine weeks, eight students will be exposed to a broad range of scientific issues relating to global climate change and to a diverse, interdisciplinary research environment. Activities include individual and supervised research, group readings and discussions, cohort-building, exposure to the national scientific community, professional skill development and guidance concerning graduate education in climate science.

During the summer program, students will work independently, in teams, and with their mentors to further understanding of physical and biogeochemical processes that influence the Earth's climate system on time scales relevant to a human lifetime. The research fields are diverse, including atmospheric, oceanic, terrestrial, and polar systems. The research projects cover a range of disciplines, including atmospheric chemistry, marine and terrestrial biogeochemistry, air/sea gas exchange, ocean circulation, sea ice and ice-sheet dynamics, and paleoclimatology. During the course of their project, the students will gain hands-on experience with geochemical analysis, remote sensing, data analysis, and/or numerical simulation.

The organizers seek to recruit from a wide range of institutions to expand the number and diversity of students seeking careers in the fields of Biogeochemistry and Climate by providing a unique educational experience to qualified students from undergraduate institutions. It especially targets students from institutions that do not have active research programs (or have only limited programs) in this field, and to students who are members of historically underrepresented groups in the Earth Sciences.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the Research Experience for Undergraduates Site in Biogeochemistry and Climate Change (BCC) at the University of California, Irvine is to entrain talented students from underrepresented groups and non-research active institutions into the climate sciences, and to prepare them for entry into graduate programs. This goal was accomplished by recruiting broadly from a wide range of institutions, and providing a positive research experience in a supportive environment.  The UCI BCC REU experience combined individual, supervised research, group readings/discussions, cohort-building, professional skill development, exposure to the national scientific community, and guidance towards graduate education in climate science (program selection, admission, funding, and expectations). 

The scientific focus of this REU site is on reducing the uncertainties in our understanding of climate change on the time scale of a human lifetime.  The research mentors were faculty from the Department of Earth System Science at the University of California Irvine (UCI). The research projects available to REU students covered a range of disciplines, including atmospheric chemistry, marine and terrestrial biogeochemistry, air/sea gas exchange, ocean circulation, sea ice and ice-sheet dynamics, and paleoclimatology.  During the course of the summer program, the students received hands-on training in the use of research tools that included laboratory analysis, field ecology and biogeochemistry measurements, numerical modeling, and remote sensing.  In addition to their own research project, the students attended scientific lectures, participate in scientific discussions, and attended workshops on science ethics, scientific communication, graduate programs, and career paths in Earth Science.

This grant funded the UCI REU site program in Biogeochemistry and Climate Change for three summers (2011-13).  The program consisted of eight weeks on site at the University of California, Irvine, plus optional participation in a national scientific meeting. Residual funding was used to support students engaging in research during the academic year (2013/14). An REU alumni page (http://www.ess.uci.edu/reualumni) was established to keep track of the accomplishments of former undergraduate researchers. The website includes presentations and publications resulting from REU research. Some information is included about the current status of the students, and their achievements since their participation in our REU site program. Of the 25 students supported by this grant, 16 are female, 12 are underrepresented (4 Latino, 1 American Indian or Alaska Native, 9 first generation college student), 21 are from institutions with limited research opportunities, and 3 of those 25 are from community colleges. Based on this information 15 of 25 UCI REU students either presented results at national science meetings and/or published results in the peer-reviewed literature to date. We continue to see the benefits of the program in terms of publications and further education.
